outputValidation.content:
{
  "problem_id": "P02",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 1.85,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "Reported to 3 significant figures based on the input masses/percent."
  },
  "method": "Work from the pure CaCO3 content. The sample mass is 5.00 g and it is 84.0% CaCO3, so m(CaCO3) = 5.00 × 0.840 = 4.20 g. Convert to moles using the given molar mass: n(CaCO3) = 4.20 g ÷ 100.1 g mol-1 = 0.04196 mol. From the balanced equation CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O, 1 mol CaCO3 produces 1 mol CO2, so n(CO2) = 0.04196 mol. Convert to mass with Mr(CO2) = 44.0: m(CO2) = 0.04196 × 44.0 = 1.848 g, which rounds to 1.85 g (3 s.f.).",
  "key_equations": [
    "m(CaCO3) = sample mass × (percent/100)",
    "n = mass/Mr",
    "m = n × Mr"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L25",
    "L26",
    "L33",
    "L34"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Only 4.20 g of CaCO3 is present, so CO2 produced must be less than 4.20 g; 1.85 g is reasonable.",
    "The reaction shows a 1:1 mol ratio for CaCO3 to CO2, so moles of CO2 should equal moles of CaCO3."
  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P05",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.89,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "Reported to 2 decimal places (≈3 significant figures) based on input data."
  },
  "method": "Convert the electrolysis time to seconds: 30.0 min × 60 = 1800 s. Use the definition of current (A = C s-1) to get the charge passed: Q = I×t = 1.50 × 1800 = 2700 C. The Faraday constant is 96,500 C mol-1 (of electrons), so the moles of electrons transferred are n(e-) = Q/96500 = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol e-. From the cathode half-equation Cu2+ + 2e- → Cu, 2 mol e- deposit 1 mol Cu, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Convert to mass using Ar(Cu) = 63.55 g mol-1: m(Cu) = 0.01399 × 63.55 = 0.890 g, which rounds to 0.89 g.",
  "key_equations": [
    "F = 96,500 C mol-1",
    "Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu",
    "m = n × Ar"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L19",
    "L24",
    "L51",
    "L52"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "If current or time were zero, charge and mass would be zero; here both are positive so a positive mass is expected.",
    "Order of magnitude: 2700 C corresponds to 2700/96500 ≈ 0.028 mol e-, giving ≈0.014 mol Cu, i.e. under 1 g, consistent with 0.89 g."
  ]
}

critical_issues: P01: The numeric value is given as 0.02 while the text and precision_note claim 3 s.f. (should be written as 0.0200 mol dm-3 to match 25.0, 0.200, 250.0). This is a presentation/rounding inconsistency that could confuse downstream checking, though the underlying calculation described is correct (L16, L29).
value.summary: All six JSON outputs are consistent with the report data and equations, with no fabricated inputs or unsupported quantitative claims. Stoichiometry, dilution, titration, bond-enthalpy estimation, Faraday’s law electrolysis, and Kc calculations all use only provided constants/relations and the arithmetic matches the stated working (L14–L21, L23–L27, L28–L59). Key caveats are included where appropriate (P04 correctly notes bond energies give an estimate; P06 reports Kc as unitless per L21). Line引用
